Okay, my name's Sa, Sa Hansa, and I was born in Mauritius, which is a small island near the bottom of South Africa.
I was born in 1969, many years ago, and shall I say in Patrona, and I'll have a go at saying it in Patrona.
My name is Sa Hansa, I was born in Mauritius in 1969.
Incredible. And growing up, yeah, growing up in Mauritius, because you grew up there of course, can you just tell us what you remember about the area that you grew up in?
Okay, I came to London with my parents when I was a year old, and we have been to Mauritius on holidays.
My earliest memory is actually in London, South, when I was about three or four years old.
Just remembering having a happy, happy family home, playing in the garden.
We had a beautiful garden, lots of roses, and it was so peaceful and relaxing, no worries back then.
And what type of other fun things can you remember about actually growing up, was there certain games that you'd play with friends and things like that as well?
Yeah, yeah. In school we used to play a lot of skipping and hand games, I don't know what they were called, but they were like movements, and we'd sing a poem along with it.
And we used to play a lot of rounders, a lot of kind of thinking games, and doing a lot of reading.
We used to read a lot of books in our free time, a lot of Eany Blighton books. She was very popular back then.
And with my two brothers, I'd play sort of running games, and we'd chase each other and tease each other.
I have two brothers, one is, they're both younger than me, one is a few years younger than me, and the other one's probably about 11 years younger than me.
What was the experiences also, visiting Norwich? Did you visit quite young too? All the way growing up? What was those visits like?
I remember going back to Mauritius when I was about maybe four years old. I remember a wedding, my cousin got married, and we had a lovely time at the wedding.
We'd go back maybe every few years, we'd go on a holiday, see the family, my grandmother still lives there, and who lived there at the time, she's no longer around.
Unfortunately none of my grandparents are around now, but we used to go there and spend good family times together.
And as you said about the wedding as well, are there other events that are sticking inside your mind that you can remember? It could be in Norwich or even here as well in your upbringing.
Various events. As a child I think one of the most fun events I remember was celebrating Queen Elizabeth II's silver jubilee.
We had a big street party, and the whole neighbourhood got together, and we had races, games, cakes, drinks. It was a wonderful community spirit. That's one of my favourites.
Where were you living? Where was this? This was in East London.
Traveling or being around London, is there any other places you are able to visit?
I've been to different parks.

Yes, both my parents were British citizens, but they decided that as a family we'd have a better life here in the UK.
Not long after I was born, my dad actually studied here as well. He was already familiar with the country here.

It's just part of destiny. Some personal issues have brought us here.

Even with your experiences for Age Live and being around that level of community, why is that also important for that community and even young people in the future generation?
Why is it important to have these type of spaces?
I think it's really important actually because the next generation, there's so much that they can learn from the previous generation.
So whatever information, whatever we can do now to pass on to the next generation, hopefully it will assist them to maybe avoid making mistakes that we've made.
Or perhaps it will give them more of a sense of identity if they know where their family or friends came from.

I don't know, is it an experience or if you're talking about your environment or even if it's about Age Live, is there anything?
Well I think if, yeah I did have a good family upbringing.

It wasn't easy for them to bring us up.
At school I was the only Asian in my class. That wasn't easy.
But looking back it's made me who I am today. All of life experiences have made me who I am today.
And one thing I would like, if I could just offer some advice for the next generation, is to always be careful out there.

I think that would be my tip for them. Take care of the world, take care of the planet. That's what I'd like to pass on.

Which parts of London, like what areas have you lived in?
East London mostly. Grew up in Leighton and lived in Walthamstow. My school, I used to go to school in Leighton as well.
And in fact, I have visited one of my schools, but it's completely changed now. Even got a new name. But yeah, I've got some photographs of my school and the summer fairs that we used to have.
The guests that were invited to the summer fairs were like Captain Bird's Eye from the Fishfingers advert. I remember that well. It's weird, things that stick in my mind out of the blue.
And just to speak on those celebrations, was there in traditions as well, celebrations that you would do with the family?
Oh yeah. We celebrate, our faith is, we're Muslims, so we celebrate Ramadan, which is a whole month of fasting. And then we have Eid, which is family time, time for family to get together, eat, be merry.
And we have two Eids. We've got a smaller Eid as well, which is about three months after the month of fasting. And talking about the month of fasting, Ramadan is coming up next month, actually, so not long.
We don't celebrate Christmas. When we were younger, we used to give cards to our friends. And then as we got older, we realised, well, we don't celebrate it. Let's do it for our festival, give gifts for our festival.
And it was all new back then, like at school, nobody knew what we were talking about when we said we do fasting, for example. Why do you fast? You can't even drink water.
But so much progression has been made and a lot of people just know about it now. Whereas before, nobody understood why we fasted or what Eid was, for example.
And yeah, now a lot of people do know. So it's a good, oneness thing to explain.
I agree. And it just reminded me of what we spoke about earlier on about sharing with our children or the next generation. Can you just speak about how important that is for them to recognise these type of traditions and be immersed in the Eid and Ramadan and see the appearance of the elders doing that as well?
I think they're the fun parts of our childhood, those festivals, our festivals and Ramadan as well. And it's a very spiritual month. So I do think it's important for children to find that spiritual side in them.
And Ramadan is a very good time to find it. It just changes, it changes your life. It really does. It brings us closer to God and makes us realise so many things that we don't realise outside Ramadan. I can't explain it other than it's a very special month.
And you also talked about memorabilia and pictures and things like that. Is there something that you can hold close to your heart, so to speak, in terms of memorabilia?
Oh, yeah. I have, I think earlier I mentioned the Queen's silver jubilee. I remember receiving a mug. Well, my parents have got that. Yeah. But each time I look at, I see that in their display cabinet, the fond memories come back.
And other memorabilia are, I used to do stamp collecting and I still have some stamps. I used to be a big music fan. So I've got a few autographs of my favourite singers.
Yeah. I'd say, I'd say, yeah, they're my memorabilia. And I've been collecting more for my children, actually. Their baby, their little baby toys and their first painting at school, clothes. I've been collecting for them as well.
